title: Building Bilgewater: A Pirate Renovation

embed.description: Existing lore and narrative cues established Bilgewater as a city filled with shivering timbers, echoing yarrs, and plundering pirates - certainly a locale that's rife with opportunity for storytellers, but not unique in of itself. Though references and hat-tips are part of League's charm, leaning too heavily on existing tropes can leave players with the impression that they've been to this place before.

So, question for a Rioter. How exactly does one kill one of those menacing sea creatures?

> [{quoted}](name=CyanoPirate,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=LrAr6L3d,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2015-08-27T03:29:05.466+0000)
>
> So, question for a Rioter. How exactly does one kill one of those menacing sea creatures?

The thing that terrifies me is - they likely go after them at night.

_"Fleets leave port at sunset each night, seeking these mighty beasts."_

I'm not familiar with the background, but what can it mean that it's easier/safer/better to hunt them at night, than it is during the day?  Do they glow?    Do they get less violent at night?  Do they surface once the sun goes down??

To me it sounds as if they are nocturnal. During day they rest deep down on the bottom of the sea, and at night they surface to hunt and eat (maybe to mate?). You just can't capture them by day. I struggle to find another sensible reason to prefer going out at night :/

This is pretty much what we were thinking. We took inspiration from all the terrifying creatures in the deep, abyssal darkness of our own oceans that rise closer to the surface at night to feed, and things like squid, who mainly hunt at night. Squid fishermen go out at night and use lights to lure them to the surface - we figured that certain types of sea monster could lured be up in similar (though much more terrifying) fashion.
I guess that ties in with the Serpent Callers; the Slaughter Fleets need them to draw out the sea monsters in to the open where they can be properly dispatched.

I'd assume that they go by night because the monsters are more manageable then. If you consider that the majority of sea creatures are day goers then the same can be inferred for the serpents, krakens and whatever else. In the day navigating certain parts of the sea is likely impossible because of the sheer number of sea beasts, and potentially the fleets hunt by ambushing them while they sleep. I mean if you think about it:

- If you hunt in the day you risk having more sea monsters attack you
- They'll see you coming
- Other monsters might be attracted to "blood in the water" so to speak

Where as at night:

- Monsters are asleep and there are fewer nocturnal ones, so less risk of multi-monster attacks
- Because they're sleeping less risk of dead sea monsters attracting other predators.

I'd assume that's why. Might be some cultural beliefs as well like "The Bearded Lady sleeps in the depths at night, so we hunt her children then, lest we incur her wrath".

I think it should be about how the sea monsters react to light. Maybe the ones that live deeper underwater have adapted sensitive eyes and don't come to the surface during the day because the sun deters them. Maybe a moonless night is the best time to set up a trap, lighting a luminous "lure" that mimics the light color or pattern of a bioluminescent mating dance, or the display of a prey fish. Either way, it conjures an exciting visual for a hunt with the slaughter fleet.

Imagine a choppy sea and a slew of ships, carefully and painstakingly navigated to maintain a circular formation. The sailors all work in total darkness, relying only the least amount of deck lighting possible to stay keep pace with the other vessels. The metal clad fleet is tied together by massive cables, holding a chemical lure in place that when lit, will attract a terribly denizen of the deep to breach the waters and face the pirate's waiting barrage of wicked harpoons and hot lead!

I can almost see the seas sway and the hunters screaming, while a giant serpent thrashes in their midst, hooked and harassed while they try to blow out it's brains. Muzzle flash reflected on water. The smell of gunpowder and the creature's blood. Groaning wooden hulls and mooring lines. Terrible roars of distress, from a mighty creature brought low.

Maybe they use red-filtered light on the decks, as red light doesn't penetrate water very much (and many animals cannot discern red light).  That'd give the proceedings a very ominous and threatening tint, making blood look much brighter than anything else.  Maybe it's ruby-windowed lanterns.  Maybe it's stained glass.  Expensive, and delicate, and covered in iron mesh to protect it when the inevitable blows from the monsters hit.

(Also, don't think I didn't notice the bioluminescent comment there.  My specialist subject - woo!)

That is one heck of a picture you and MythicTwister have put together. I may have to see if I can get something written up; been meaning to start on short stories again. Obviously, the best time to start is almost 4AM. Thanks for that. :P

At least I have a hook or 3. "Help wanted. Good pay. Must be able to swim. Experience on ships a plus."

Yeah, pass that along... I want more info. I like what people are posting below your comment, too, but it just leaves more questions. This is an interesting thing to explore.

Also, the tentacles in that picture. Are the sea beasts related at all to the Void? I super envy the jobs of the people who get to think about this. As a JOB, people. Such fun.

It's nice they released concept art produced over the course of Bilgewater's reintroduction; seeing the architectural styles incorporated from across Runeterra and burial customs gives us information we might otherwise never know within the game.

Question for you: Will we see Butcher's Bridge return to the ARAM queue in a permanent state? It feels weird to have one map come out during an event (Freljord) that kept a permanent queue status, while the other (Bilgewater) just... disappeared. Wouldn't it be nice to have the two map skins randomly alternate when playing ARAM?
